statement:
Let $(W_t)_{t\in\mathbb{R}_+}$ be a standard Brownian motion. Then, its
quadratic variation exists and is given by $$[W]_t=t.$$

As Brownian motion is a martingale and, in particular, is a
semimartingale then . We just need to compute its value along a sequence
of partitions.

If $P=\{0=t_0\le t_1\le\cdots\le t_m=t\}$ is a of the interval $[0,t]$,
then the quadratic variation on $P$ is
$$[W]^P=\sum_{k=1}^m(W_{t_k}-W_{t_{k-1}})^2.$$ Using the property that
the increments $W_{t_k}-W_{t_{k-1}}$ are independent normal random
variables with mean zero and variance $t_k-t_{k-1}$, the mean and
variance of $[W]^P$ are $$\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[[W]^P\right]&=\sum_{k=1}^m\mathbb{E}\left[(W_{t_k}-W_{t_{k-1}})^2\right]=\sum_{k=1}^m(t_k-t_{k-1})=t,\\
\operatorname{Var}\left[[W]^P\right]&=\sum_{k=1}^m\operatorname{Var}\left[(W_{t_k}-W_{t_{k-1}})^2\right]=\sum_{k=1}^m2(t_k-t_{k-1})^2\\
&\le 2|P|\sum_{k=1}^m(t_k-t_{k-1})=2|P|t.\end{aligned}$$ Here,
$|P|=\max_k(t_k-t_{k-1})$ is the mesh of the partition. If
$(P_n)_{n=1,2,\ldots}$ is a sequence of partitions of $[0,t]$ with mesh
going to zero as $n\rightarrow \infty$ then,
$$\mathbb{E}\left[([W]^{P_n}-t)^2\right]\le 2|P_n|t\rightarrow 0$$ as
$n\rightarrow\infty$. This shows that $[W]^{P_n}\rightarrow t$ in the
$L^2$ norm and, in particular, converges in probability. So, $[W]_t=t$.
